</span><span><strong style="color:#000">Economy: </strong></span><span>It was a split-screen kind of day. Retail sales </span><span><a href="https://apnews.com/93e8e62393993ae78cb0df88f95d3951?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">boomed</a></span><span> a record 17.7% in May, a reassuring sign following April’s 14.7% collapse. However, Fed Chair Jerome Powell said there was “</span><span><a href="https://apnews.com/810464e6f3e1af5205000faf0ced93ac?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">significant uncertainty</a></span><span>” about an economic recovery during testimony on Capitol Hill. He also called the pandemic "a real inequality-increaser.”</span>

<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>
</span><span><strong style="color:#000">Markets: </strong></span><span>Investors chose to focus on the positive news, sending the major indexes </span><span><a href="https://www.cnbc.com/2020/06/15/stock-market-futures-open-to-close-news.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">climbing</a></span><span> for their third straight day of gains.</span>
</li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>
</span><span><strong style="color:#000">Nation: </strong></span><span>President Trump signed an </span><span><a href="https://www.nbcnews.com/politics/donald-trump/trump-signs-executive-order-policing-amid-mounting-pressure-over-lethal-n1231174?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">executive order</a></span><span> on police reform, but said he strongly opposed proposals to defund or dismantle police departments.</span>

<div class="c6 " style="margin-bottom:7px">
<!-- <![endif]-->
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
TECH
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/06/16/contact-tracing-apps-scrutinized-privacy-adoption-rates?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
Contact Tracing Apps Find Themselves in a Catch 19
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<img alt="Contact tracing phone software" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC83MjUvY29udGFjdF90cmFjaW5nX3Bob25lLnBuZyIsImJ1Y2tldCI6Im9zbG8tcHJvZHVjdGlvbiIsImVkaXRzIjp7InJlc2l6ZSI6eyJ3aWR0aCI6MTAwMCwiaGVpZ2h0IjpudWxsfX19">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>Francis Scialabba</em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">To help stop the spread of COVID-19, contact tracing apps need to track people. There’s just one problem: To help stop the spread of COVID-19, contact tracing apps need to track people.</p>
<h2 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0">New this week</h2>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Italy’s app, released Monday, <a href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/06/16/world/europe/contact-tracing-apps-europe-coronavirus.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">is built on</a> software developed by Apple and Google for public health agencies. But it has fewer users than even Quibi. With 2.7 million downloads, the app is still far away from the 60% adoption threshold experts believe is needed to forestall a second wave of infections. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Germany’s app <a href="https://www.wsj.com/articles/coronavirus-contact-tracing-apps-launch-across-europe-amid-hopes-for-broad-adoption-11592319612?mod=hp_featst_pos4&utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">launched</a> yesterday, weeks late due to disagreements about data protection. It’s also got an uphill road: In a survey, nearly 40% of Germans said they wouldn’t download it. </p>
<h2 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0">A major issue is privacy</h2>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">What do Norway, Bahrain, and Kuwait have in common? Their apps were at the top of Amnesty International’s list of most concerning COVID-19 surveillance tools. </p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>Norway </span><span><a href="https://techcrunch.com/2020/06/15/norway-pulls-its-coronavirus-contacts-tracing-app-after-privacy-watchdogs-warning/?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">suspended</a></span><span> its app Monday after a data protection watchdog issued a warning last week.</span>
</li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>The Gulf states of Bahrain and Kuwait </span><span><a href="https://www.bbc.com/news/world-middle-east-53052395?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">used</a></span><span> a similar architecture. Bahrain had users register with national ID numbers and, at one point, linked the app to a TV show.</span>
</li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Don’t forget India, which <a href="https://www.cbsnews.com/news/coronavirus-india-contact-tracing-app-privacy-data-security-concerns-aarogya-setu-forced-on-millions/?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">requires</a> train passengers, people who live in high-risk areas, and office workers to download its contact tracing app. The app collects personal info such as names, phone numbers, age, and gender. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Big picture: </strong>Critics feel these measures go beyond what’s necessary for public health and violate users’ privacy.</p>
<h2 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0">Bring it home</h2>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Contact tracing in the U.S. is <a href="https://www.nbcnews.com/tech/tech-news/coronavirus-contact-tracing-apps-were-tech-s-chance-step-they-n1230211?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">patchy</a>, since the federal government left efforts up to individual states. Some states that previously said they’d create apps have ditched plans...including California, Apple and Google's home state. </p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>At least three states </span><span><em>do</em></span><span> plan on using the Apple/Google framework for an app. </span>
</li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>And while there’s no shortage of third-party tracing apps, they’re proving </span><span><a href="https://www.engadget.com/ny-attorney-general-google-apple-regulate-contact-tracing-apps-071507732.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">tough to vet</a></span><span>.</span>
</li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Looking ahead...</strong>it’s too early to make a judgment on contact tracing apps. They could gain momentum if they’re required to enter sports games, schools, or offices.  </p>

<!-- <![endif]-->
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
RESTAURANTS
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/06/16/restaurants-face-daunting-reopening-challenges?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
Today’s Special Is Outside
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<img alt="Cleaning a table at a restuarant" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC8xMzgzL2NsZWFuaW5nX2FfdGFibGVfYXRfYV9yZXN0dWFyYW50LmpwZyIsImJ1Y2tldCI6Im9zbG8tcHJvZHVjdGlvbiIsImVkaXRzIjp7InJlc2l6ZSI6eyJ3aWR0aCI6MTAwMCwiaGVpZ2h0IjpudWxsfX19">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>Ben Hasty/MediaNews Group/Reading Eagle via Getty Images</em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">As more areas lift lockdown restrictions, the U.S.’ battered restaurant industry is <a href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/06/16/business/coronavirus-restaurants-outdoor-seating.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">tentatively wading</a> back into business. But the waters are rough. </p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>Many local governments are imposing strict capacity limits. Plus, owners have no way of gauging consumers’ willingness to grab a bite, which makes it almost impossible to predict revenue. </span></li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>With their unusually high failure rates, it’s </span><span><a href="https://www.wsj.com/articles/running-on-fumes-restaurants-trying-to-reopen-face-cash-crunch-11592299802?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">tough for restaurants</a></span><span> to lock down financing. And when they do, it can come with interest rates in the 25% neighborhood. </span>
</li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Just the act of reopening a location is expensive, potentially reaching into five figures. </p>
<h2 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0">One solution? Al fresco dining </h2>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Several city governments have waived fees and accelerated permitting processes so that restaurants can bring tables out on patios and sidewalks—even streets and <a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/05/08/revenge-parking-lot?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">parking lots</a>. </p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>This spring, outdoor seating increased 10x compared to last year, according to OpenTable. </span></li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">But moving tables outside means flies in your milkshake and otherwise less-than-ideal circumstances. Dropping fees will lead to less revenue for city governments, and with coronavirus cases climbing in 22 states as of Saturday, restaurants could be forced <a href="https://www.cbsnews.com/news/coronavirus-restaurants-again-shutting-their-doors-as-coronavirus-flares/?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">back into hibernation</a>.</p>

<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">

<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
LEGAL
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/06/16/pge-pleads-guilty-dozens-manslaughter-charges?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
PG&E: “We Did It”
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding-right:15px;padding-bottom:15px;padding-left:15px;padding-top:0px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Yesterday, in a proceeding livestreamed via YouTube from a California courtroom, PG&E CEO Bill Johnson <a href="https://apnews.com/67810cb4d9b6b90e451415b76215d6c9?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">said</a> “guilty, your honor” 84 times to a judge. Each time represented one victim of Northern California’s Camp Fire, set off by PG&E equipment in 2018.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">That means PG&E legally acknowledged that its faulty electrical grid was to blame for the devastation, <a href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/06/16/business/energy-environment/pge-camp-fire-california-wildfires.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">an ultra-unusual move</a> for a company. The utility, California’s largest, pleaded guilty to 84 counts of involuntary manslaughter and one count of illegally setting a fire. </p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>It agreed to pay the maximum fine of $3.5 million, plus $500,000 for the cost of the investigation. </span></li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Zoom out: </strong>This is only one of several battles PG&E is dealing with. Its current bankruptcy deal includes a $13.5 billion payout to victims, and the California Public Utilities Commission fined it nearly $2 billion for its negligence.</p>

<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
INFRASTRUCTURE
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/06/16/trump-administration-reportedly-drafting-1t-infrastructure-bill?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
Big Crane Energy
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<img alt="Crane building a road" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC8xMzg3L2NyYW5lX2J1aWxkaW5nX2Ffcm9hZC5qcGciLCJidWNrZXQiOiJvc2xvLXByb2R1Y3Rpb24iLCJlZGl0cyI6eyJyZXNpemUiOnsid2lkdGgiOjEwMDAsImhlaWdodCI6bnVsbH19fQ==">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>Pixabay</em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">When the first two cups of coffee don’t do the trick, go straight for the Red Bull. The White House is <a href="https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2020-06-16/trump-team-weighs-1-trillion-for-infrastructure-to-spur-economy?sref=KkPzpZvz&utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">reportedly drafting</a> a $1 trillion infrastructure proposal to rev up the economy. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">According to those reports, most of that would go to classic infrastructure projects—roads and bridges—but about a quarter would be set aside for 21st century information highways: rural broadband and 5G wireless networks (<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/emerging-tech/guides/5g-in-2020?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">here's what they are</a>). </p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>The administration may reportedly try piggybacking the proposal on a current infrastructure funding law, which needs renewal before Sept. 30, or packaging it in a new round of pandemic relief.</span></li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Still, with that price tag the administration could find opposition on Capitol Hill after multiple rounds of emergency pandemic funds racked up a huge bill. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Big picture:</strong> Depending on which economist you ask, we’re in a recession, out of one, or waiting for the worst to come. The government’s busy looking for ways to boost output, and massive infrastructure spending could mark a shift from the "relief" phase to the  "stimulus" part.</p>

<tr>

<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">

<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
ROBOTICS
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/06/16/boston-dynamics-makes-advanced-robot-spot-available-general-sale?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
Mom, Can We Keep Him?
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<!--[if mso]>
<img alt="Boston Dynamics robot Spot " style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" height=377 src="https://media.giphy.com/media/U86wHVI53I3TPgLaIt/giphy.gif">
<![endif]-->
<!--[if !mso]>--><!-- -->
<img class="story-header-image" alt="Boston Dynamics robot Spot " style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" src="https://media.giphy.com/media/U86wHVI53I3TPgLaIt/giphy.gif">
<!--<![endif]-->
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>Giphy/Boston Dynamics</em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">If your business is wanting for a headless, tailless robotic “dog,” have we got the pack of hounds for you. Boston Dynamics’s internet-famous Spot is <a href="https://www.theverge.com/21292684/boston-dynamics-spot-robot-on-sale-price?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">now available</a> for general sale. Up until yesterday, the firm only leased Spots to select clients in an “Early Adopter Program,” but now any U.S. business with $74,500 to spare can buy one. </p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>Spot is a highly sophisticated robot that knows how to </span><span><a href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=0ESp9ZlbRfs&utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">hold the door</a></span><span>, </span><span><a href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=zyaocKS3sfg&utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">pull a rickshaw</a></span><span>, </span><span><a href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=kHBcVlqpvZ8&utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">moonwalk</a></span><span>, and treat fire hydrants with respect. Boston Dynamics claims it's the most advanced mobile robot in the world. </span>
</li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Why do businesses need a robot best friend? </strong>Commercial customers will delegate tasks to Spot that are either dangerous or mind-numbingly boring for a human. Boston Dynamics lead robotics engineer Zack Jackowski gave The Verge an example of carrying a camera around a factory 40x/day and taking the same photo each time.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">But for everything it<em> can</em> do, Spot can’t yet scale a) ladders or b) the coronavirus pandemic. Boston Dynamics is working on improvements in teleoperations that allow potential customers to demo Spot from afar.</p>

<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Two words, lots of good: portfolio diversification</strong>. <th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
BREW'S BETS
</h3>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding-right:15px;padding-bottom:15px;padding-left:15px;padding-top:0px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Road trip tips: </strong>Here’s <a href="https://www.usatoday.com/in-depth/travel/experience/america/2020/06/10/covid-19-road-trips-find-out-how-stay-safe-and-see-whats-open/3155769001/" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">a guide</a> on how to take a road trip safely right now, an <a href="https://www.forbes.com/sites/irenelevine/2020/06/14/if-you-gotta-go-are-public-restrooms-safe-on-a-road-trip/#43cfb33a25d6" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">in-depth article</a> about using public restrooms, and <a href="https://www.travelandleisure.com/trip-ideas/road-trips/best-midwest-road-trips-in-the-us" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">seven Midwest road trips</a> to add to your bucket list. You can grab even more road trip resources from a recent edition of our <a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/06/08/essentials-issue-26-hit-road.html" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">Essentials</a> newsletter.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">If you are flying...</strong>know the air filtration actually keeps the cabin pretty safe. But here are some <a href="https://www.insider.com/what-are-health-risks-plane-air-travel-2020-6" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">experts’ opinions</a> on the risks of flying during COVID-19, plus <a href="https://www.npr.org/sections/goatsandsoda/2020/05/15/848706362/coronavirus-faqs-how-risky-is-it-to-fly-is-there-any-way-to-reduce-the-risks" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">other FAQs</a> you may have.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Biohacking lite: </strong>Everything you've ever wanted to know about how the human body works, plus a whole lot more. <a href="https://karpathy.github.io/2020/06/11/biohacking-lite/" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">Check it out</a>.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><sup style="display: inline-block; line-height: 16px;">*This is sponsored advertising content</sup></p>

style=\"color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;\"\u003e\n\u003cfont color=\"#000000\"\u003e\nContact Tracing Apps Find Themselves in a Catch 19\n\u003c/font\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003c/h1\u003e\n\u003c/td\u003e\n\u003c/tr\u003e\n\u003c/table\u003e\n\u003cimg alt=\"Contact tracing phone software\" style=\"display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;\" width=\"670\" class=\"story-header-image\" src=\"https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC83MjUvY29udGFjdF90cmFjaW5nX3Bob25lLnBuZyIsImJ1Y2tldCI6Im9zbG8tcHJvZHVjdGlvbiIsImVkaXRzIjp7InJlc2l6ZSI6eyJ3aWR0aCI6MTAwMCwiaGVpZ2h0IjpudWxsfX19\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;\"\u003e\n\u003csmall\u003e\u003cem\u003eFrancis Scialabba\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/small\u003e\n\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" style=\"border-collapse: collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"padding:15px\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eTo help stop the spread of COVID-19, contact tracing apps need to track people. There’s just one problem: To help stop the spread of COVID-19, contact tracing apps need to track people.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003ch2 style=\"font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0\"\u003eNew this week\u003c/h2\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eItaly’s app, released Monday, \u003ca href=\"https://www.nytimes.com/2020/06/16/world/europe/contact-tracing-apps-europe-coronavirus.html?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eis built on\u003c/a\u003e software developed by Apple and Google for public health agencies. But it has fewer users than even Quibi. With 2.7 million downloads, the app is still far away from the 60% adoption threshold experts believe is needed to forestall a second wave of infections. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eGermany’s app \u003ca href=\"https://www.wsj.com/articles/coronavirus-contact-tracing-apps-launch-across-europe-amid-hopes-for-broad-adoption-11592319612?mod=hp_featst_pos4\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003elaunched\u003c/a\u003e yesterday, weeks late due to disagreements about data protection. It’s also got an uphill road: In a survey, nearly 40% of Germans said they wouldn’t download it. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003ch2 style=\"font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0\"\u003eA major issue is privacy\u003c/h2\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eWhat do Norway, Bahrain, and Kuwait have in common? Their apps were at the top of Amnesty International’s list of most concerning COVID-19 surveillance tools. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003eNorway \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://techcrunch.com/2020/06/15/norway-pulls-its-coronavirus-contacts-tracing-app-after-privacy-watchdogs-warning/?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003esuspended\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e its app Monday after a data protection watchdog issued a warning last week.\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003eThe Gulf states of Bahrain and Kuwait \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://www.bbc.com/news/world-middle-east-53052395?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eused\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e a similar architecture. Bahrain had users register with national ID numbers and, at one point, linked the app to a TV show.\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eDon’t forget India, which \u003ca href=\"https://www.cbsnews.com/news/coronavirus-india-contact-tracing-app-privacy-data-security-concerns-aarogya-setu-forced-on-millions/?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003erequires\u003c/a\u003e train passengers, people who live in high-risk areas, and office workers to download its contact tracing app. The app collects personal info such as names, phone numbers, age, and gender. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eBig picture: \u003c/strong\u003eCritics feel these measures go beyond what’s necessary for public health and violate users’ privacy.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003ch2 style=\"font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0\"\u003eBring it home\u003c/h2\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eContact tracing in the U.S. is \u003ca href=\"https://www.nbcnews.com/tech/tech-news/coronavirus-contact-tracing-apps-were-tech-s-chance-step-they-n1230211?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003epatchy\u003c/a\u003e, since the federal government left efforts up to individual states. Some states that previously said they’d create apps have ditched plans...including California, Apple and Google's home state. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003eAt least three states \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003cem\u003edo\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e plan on using the Apple/Google framework for an app. \u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003eAnd while there’s no shortage of third-party tracing apps, they’re proving \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://www.engadget.com/ny-attorney-general-google-apple-regulate-contact-tracing-apps-071507732.html?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003etough to vet\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e.\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eLooking ahead...\u003c/strong\u003eit’s too early to make a judgment on contact tracing apps. They could gain momentum if they’re required to enter sports games, schools, or offices.  \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c!-- SOCIAL LINKS --\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"padding:15px\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eAs more areas lift lockdown restrictions, the U.S.’ battered restaurant industry is \u003ca href=\"https://www.nytimes.com/2020/06/16/business/coronavirus-restaurants-outdoor-seating.html?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003etentatively wading\u003c/a\u003e back into business. But the waters are rough. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eMany local governments are imposing strict capacity limits. Plus, owners have no way of gauging consumers’ willingness to grab a bite, which makes it almost impossible to predict revenue. \u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003eWith their unusually high failure rates, it’s \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://www.wsj.com/articles/running-on-fumes-restaurants-trying-to-reopen-face-cash-crunch-11592299802?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003etough for restaurants\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e to lock down financing. And when they do, it can come with interest rates in the 25% neighborhood. \u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eJust the act of reopening a location is expensive, potentially reaching into five figures. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003ch2 style=\"font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0\"\u003eOne solution? Al fresco dining \u003c/h2\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eSeveral city governments have waived fees and accelerated permitting processes so that restaurants can bring tables out on patios and sidewalks—even streets and \u003ca href=\"https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/05/08/revenge-parking-lot?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eparking lots\u003c/a\u003e. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eThis spring, outdoor seating increased 10x compared to last year, according to OpenTable. \u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eBut moving tables outside means flies in your milkshake and otherwise less-than-ideal circumstances. Dropping fees will lead to less revenue for city governments, and with coronavirus cases climbing in 22 states as of Saturday, restaurants could be forced \u003ca href=\"https://www.cbsnews.com/news/coronavirus-restaurants-again-shutting-their-doors-as-coronavirus-flares/?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eback into hibernation\u003c/a\u003e.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c!-- SOCIAL LINKS --\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eYesterday, in a proceeding livestreamed via YouTube from a California courtroom, PG\u0026E CEO Bill Johnson \u003ca href=\"https://apnews.com/67810cb4d9b6b90e451415b76215d6c9?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003esaid\u003c/a\u003e “guilty, your honor” 84 times to a judge. Each time represented one victim of Northern California’s Camp Fire, set off by PG\u0026E equipment in 2018.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eThat means PG\u0026E legally acknowledged that its faulty electrical grid was to blame for the devastation, \u003ca href=\"https://www.nytimes.com/2020/06/16/business/energy-environment/pge-camp-fire-california-wildfires.html?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ean ultra-unusual move\u003c/a\u003e for a company. The utility, California’s largest, pleaded guilty to 84 counts of involuntary manslaughter and one count of illegally setting a fire. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eIt agreed to pay the maximum fine of $3.5 million, plus $500,000 for the cost of the investigation. \u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eZoom out: \u003c/strong\u003eThis is only one of several battles PG\u0026E is dealing with. style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eWhen the first two cups of coffee don’t do the trick, go straight for the Red Bull. The White House is \u003ca href=\"https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2020-06-16/trump-team-weighs-1-trillion-for-infrastructure-to-spur-economy?sref=KkPzpZvz\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ereportedly drafting\u003c/a\u003e a $1 trillion infrastructure proposal to rev up the economy. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eAccording to those reports, most of that would go to classic infrastructure projects—roads and bridges—but about a quarter would be set aside for 21st century information highways: rural broadband and 5G wireless networks (\u003ca href=\"https://www.morningbrew.com/emerging-tech/guides/5g-in-2020?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ehere's what they are\u003c/a\u003e). \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eThe administration may reportedly try piggybacking the proposal on a current infrastructure funding law, which needs renewal before Sept. 30, or packaging it in a new round of pandemic relief.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eStill, with that price tag the administration could find opposition on Capitol Hill after multiple rounds of emergency pandemic funds racked up a huge bill. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eBig picture:\u003c/strong\u003e Depending on which economist you ask, we’re in a recession, out of one, or waiting for the worst to come. collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"padding:15px\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eIf your business is wanting for a headless, tailless robotic “dog,” have we got the pack of hounds for you. Boston Dynamics’s internet-famous Spot is \u003ca href=\"https://www.theverge.com/21292684/boston-dynamics-spot-robot-on-sale-price?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003enow available\u003c/a\u003e for general sale. Up until yesterday, the firm only leased Spots to select clients in an “Early Adopter Program,” but now any U.S. business with $74,500 to spare can buy one. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003eSpot is a highly sophisticated robot that knows how to \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=0ESp9ZlbRfs\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ehold the door\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e, \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=zyaocKS3sfg\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003epull a rickshaw\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e, \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=kHBcVlqpvZ8\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003emoonwalk\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e, and treat fire hydrants with respect. Boston Dynamics claims it's the most advanced mobile robot in the world. \u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eWhy do businesses need a robot best friend? \u003c/strong\u003eCommercial customers will delegate tasks to Spot that are either dangerous or mind-numbingly boring for a human. Boston Dynamics lead robotics engineer Zack Jackowski gave The Verge an example of carrying a camera around a factory 40x/day and taking the same photo each time.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eBut for everything it\u003cem\u003e can\u003c/em\u003e do, Spot can’t yet scale a) ladders or b) the coronavirus pandemic.
